bioghist.p: Father Thomas Cooke Middleton (1842-1923) was born in Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania, to a Quaker family. He was baptized at the age of 12 with his entire family. He entered the Augustinian novitiate at Tolentine, Italy, in 1858, and was ordained to the priesthood in 1864. In 1865, Father Middleton returned to the United States and Villanova College, where he served and lived for the next 58 years. At Villanova College he was a teacher, Prefect of Studies of the College, Archivist, and Secretary and Socius of the Province. He also served as president of Villanova College from 1876 to 1878 and College Librarian from 1865 to 1923. In 1884, Father Middleton helped organize the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, of which he was the first President. He was the author of many essays on local Catholic history and the history of the Order of Saint Augustine, including the Introduction to the Oratorian translations of Life of Saint Thomas of Villanova. He also prepared an historical sketch of Villanova College which was published in 1893, the year of the College's 50th anniversary. Middleton Hall, the Health Center at Villanova University, is named in his honor.

scopecontent.p: The Thomas Cooke Middleton, O.S.A. papers consist of a handwritten set of instructions for the 1877 commencement ceremony. Includes lists of refreshments, instructions to ushers, an invitation list, and a to-do list (with items such as "piano tuned," "fences whitewashed," "notify Penna. R.R. about cars," and "rosettes for speakers"). The collection also includes a volume with a list of students and teachers (1843-1879) and a list of Augustinians in the USA as of May 30, 1889.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
